texts.shortText:
Dorsal surface black with a small, low dorsal fin that has a wide base and is preceded by a distinct hump. Dorsal surface of head with three rows of rounded, raised tubercles, each bearing a single hair, other tubercles present on chin and sides of jaw. Flippers extremely long (>30% body length) with knobs along their leading edge, dark above and white below. Underside of head white, with about 30 distinct throat pleats, belly with variable amounts of white. Tail flukes with distinctly serrated trailing edge and variable white patches on underside (exact pattern of these can be used to identify and track individuals).

Blow a tall, single, bushy plume. At a distance best identified by the long flippers, which are obvious when breaching or rolling at the surface, and by the white underside to the tail when diving.
Maximum length of males about 14 m and of females 15 m and mass up to about 40 t.

Global: Worldwide, migrating between summer feeding ground near the poles and winter breeding grounds in lower latitudes

Local/Regional: Whole region.

Although they occur worldwide, the populations in the N and S hemispheres mostly remain separate (as their migration patterns are displaced by six months). The Southern population spend the summer in the Antarctic, where they fatten up on copepods and krill. They then migrate to warmer waters of various regions in spring to breed. The African sub-population is thus transitory in our waters, passing through as they migrate between Antarctic feeding grounds and breeding grounds off east and west Africa. The northern migration peaks in our waters in June and July and the southern migration in September.

Undertake a variety of behaviours, including spectacular breaches and smacking of the water surface with the tail. Usually expose the tail flukes when diving, revealing their characteristic white underside and scalloped trailing edge.

Humpback whales are also well-known for their complicated songs, which are sung mostly on the wintering grounds and can last for 10–15 minutes. Almost all singers are large, single males and the songs are thought to either attract females or assert dominance between males.

Humpback whales were seriously depleted by whaling, with 24 700 individuals from just the African population alone being killed between only 1908 to 1915. The species was given full protection from 1964, but thousands were still killed illegally thereafter, at least until an International Observer System was implemented in 1972. There has been a substantial recovery since that time and the East African population was estimated at 12 000 in 2003 – which modelling suggests might be 79% of the original population.

The surfaces of humpback whiles are colonised by various other commensal species, including whale lice (Cyamus), whale barnacles (Coronula) and stalked barnacles (Conchoderma) –  see those pages for further details.

Lunge feeders, which surface horizontally or vertically with the mouth open and the throat grooves bagging, taking in a huge gulp of water and associated food organisms. The water is then sieved out though the baleen plates, which number over 300 in each upper jaw, each plate up to 100 cm long, and the food swallowed. Well known for their unusual habit of descending below fish shoals and concentrating these with a bubble-net, a group of whales then engulfing the trapped fish as they rise from directly below.

Feed on small crustaceans, such as copepods, krill and euphausiids, as well as on small shoaling fish.

The age at maturity is estimated to vary from 5–10 between different populations and the length at maturity is about 12.5 m. Births take place in July to October with a peak in August and length at birth is about 4–4.5. m and lactation extends for 10–11 months. Females can fall pregnant again almost immediately after giving birth, but the usual calving interval is two years. Both sexes mate with multiple partners.
Unlikely to be confused with other regional whales due to the enormous flippers, knobs on the head and white underside to the tail.

Ashton, N & Ashton, B (2012). Watching Whales and Dolphins in Southern Africa. Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 76).

Best, PB (2007). Whales and Dolphins of the Southern African Subregion. Cambridge University Press (p. 41).
